"Polyethylene terephthalate (PET/PETE) is one of the most commonly used plastics in " "consumer products.
" "It has a low risk of leaching (when chemicals from the plastics transfer into the food) " "and is FDA approved. 
" "The benefits of PTE include: lightweight, smooth, shatter resistant, and can withstand " "temperatures ranging from -20 F to 120 F. 

"
"PET products: Soft drinks, water bottles, clear hinged containers, peanut butter " "containers, salad dressing bottles, and oven-ready cooking trays 

"
"Proper disposal: Rinsed and dried 

"
"Method of disposal: Curbside recycle programs"

"High-density polyethylene (HDPE) is another commonly used plastic that differentiates itself " "by being more durable/flexible than other plastic types. 
" "It has a low risk of leaching and is safe to be reused. 
" "The benefits of HDPE include: Stiff, durable, affordable, and can withstand " "temperatures ranging from -40 F to 266 F. 

"
"HDPE products: Milk jugs, juice bottles, cleaner bottles, trash can liners, and flower pots

"
"Proper disposal: Rinsed and dried

"
"Method of disposal: Curbside recycle programs"

"Polyvinyl chloride (PVC) comes in two basic forms, rigid and flexible. Like HDPE, PVC is very " "durable. It's rigid form is often used in construction and its flexible form can be found" "in many household products and appliances. 

"
"The benefits of PVC include: durable, weather resistant, non-conductive, chemical resistant, " "and can withstand temperatures ranging from -0 F to 150 F. 

"
"Some PVC products: Window cleaner bottles, detergent bottles, garden hoses, pipe, "
"Proper disposal: N/A 

"
"Method of disposal: Look up a local recycling center or non-profit who will take it"

"Low-density polyethylene (LDPE) is a safe product to reuse and won't leach any chemicals." " Unlike its counterpart HDPE, LDPE is quite flexible when compared to most plastics. 
" " 
" "The benefits of LDPE include: , smooth, shatter resistant, and can withstand " "temperatures ranging from -58 F to 185 F. 

"
"LDPE products: Plastic bread bags. food wrappings, squeezable bottles, and cereal bags

"
"Proper disposal: No contaminants/Washed and rinsed

"
"Method of disposal: Curbside recycle programs"

"Polypropylene (PP) is known to handle high-temperatures better than most plastics so often" "you'll find it used for hot liquids and foods. A good identifier for PP would be how clear the" " product is. Often polypropylene is clear. 

"
"The benefits of PP include: durable, lightweight, high melting point, and can withstand " "temperatures ranging from 0 F to 250 F. 

"
"PP products: Take out containers, plates/bowls, straws, auto parts, and cups

"
"Proper disposal: Rinsed and Dried

"
"Method of disposal: Becoming increasingly accepted by curbside recycling programs so check, " "but a good program that accepts these plastics by mail is Preserve Gimme 5."

"Polystyrene (PS) is a bit of an odd plastic. It is considered recyclable but cost wise it " "isn't. Another word for this product you may know is styrofoam, which is a stretched/expanded " "version of polystyrene. 

"
"The benefits of PS include: lightweight, versatile, cheap, and can withstand " "temperatures ranging from 20 F to 180 F. 

"
"PS products: Disposable plates, disposable cups, egg cartons, straws, and shipping pellets

"
"Proper disposal: N/A (Read below)

"
"Method of disposal: N/A as polystyrene isn't accepted as it is lightweight but doesn't break " "down easily. Recycling is calculated by weight so it isn't profitable to accept."
